bites.bite: In United Arab Emirates, there are 12 funder_ref(s) working in 16 sector_group(s).
The largest sector_group is Health, general with 12 reports followed by Basic health with 11 reports.

The largest activity_url is http://d-portal.org/q.html?aid=XM-DAC-928-AE-2020-21-01.001.EM01.UAE01 with 9 reports followed by http://d-portal.org/q.html?aid=XM-DAC-928-AE-2020-21-04.001.EM01.UAE01 with 3 reports.
The largest funder_ref is XM-DAC-928 with 36 reports followed by XM-DAC-41302 with 10 reports.
The largest reporting is World Health Organization with 36 reports followed by International Labour Organization (ILO) with 10 reports.
The largest reporting_ref is XM-DAC-928 with 36 reports followed by XM-DAC-41302 with 10 reports.

bite: Updated policy guidelines and technical tools to support the adoption and implementation of the global strategy and targets for tuberculosis prevention, care and control after 2015, covering the three pillars: (1) integrated, patient-centred care and prevention; (2) bold policies and supportive systems; and (3) intensified research and innovation
Implementation and monitoring of the global vaccine action plan, with emphasis on strengthening service delivery and immunization monitoring in order to achieve the goals for the Decade of Vaccines
Development and/or implementation of national multisectoral policies and plans to prevent and control noncommunicable diseases accelerated

Improved national health financing strategies aimed at moving towards universal health coverage

Comprehensive monitoring of the global, regional and country health situation, trends, inequalities and determinants, using global standards, including data collection and analysis to address data gaps and system performance assessment
Knowledge management policies, tools, networks and resources developed and used by WHO and countries to strengthen their capacity to generate, share and apply knowledge

Updated policy guidelines and technical tools to support the implementation of the End TB Strategy and efforts to meet targets for tuberculosis prevention, care and control after 2015, covering the three pillars:  (1) integrated, patient-centred care and prevention; (2) bold policies and supportive systems; and (3) intensified research and innovation

Updated policy recommendations, strategic and technical guidelines on vector control, diagnostic testing, antimalarial treatment, including for hard-to-reach populations, integrated management of febrile illness, surveillance and disaggregation of data, epidemic detection and response for accelerated malaria reduction and elimination

Enhanced coordination of activities, multistakeholder engagement and action across sectors in collaborative work with relevant United Nations system organizations, other intergovernmental organizations and non-State actors, to support governments to meet their commitments on the prevention and control of noncommunicable diseases

Strengthened evidence base, prioritization and uptake of WHO generated norms and standards and improved research capacity and the ability to effectively and sustainably scale up innovations, including digital technology, in countries.

Strengthened evidence base, prioritization and uptake of WHO generated norms and standards and improved research capacity and the ability to effectively and sustainably scale up innovations, including digital technology, in countries.

This project derives from the longstanding collaboration established with the Friuli Venezia Giulia Region, since the joint declaration signed between UNIDO ITPO Italy and Autonomous Region Friuli Venezia Giulia on 8th May 2015.

The objective of the project is to create linkages and networks between regional, national and international innovators, industry and public and private technology producers and research centres. The Innovation Bridge Trieste – Dubai 2020 foresee a programme of activities to anticipate and link two major events: Trieste ESOF 2020 - European City of Science and Expo Dubai 2020 “Connecting Minds, Creating the Future”.
Within this context, the project will be aimed at supporting local and international stakeholders to find innovative and sustainable solutions for inclusive economic development. Therefore, to achieve transformative changes and to transfer technology and know-how for entrepreneurship, innovation needs to be scaled-up and spread globally.

UNIDO ITPO Italy will act as honest broker on facilitating international partnerships, stimulating know-how and best practices exchange, as well as the promotion of the innovations and cooperation opportunities.

Short general project overview:The United Arab Emirates (UAE) faces major challenges in terms of water security and water safety in the urban environment. Large and continuous growth means that living environments need to be expanded and preserved and the water supply and purification must be realised more efficiently. In addition to many innovations and investments required in this context, the (water) infrastructure in the urban delta and coastal waters must be prepared to achieve the water ambitions of the UAE, including through dredging. Although a lot of attention is paid to water and energy savings in the industry, dredging is still carried out through conventional techniques. This sector is extremely polluting because large ships are needed to operate the heavy dredging systems. The systems themselves also have a negative impact underwater because they cause water obfuscation (turbidity) which suffocates benthic organisms and coral. In addition, dredging by large ships has a negative effect on the coastal islands. Among other things for these reasons large ships are exiled off the coast of the UAE. This is an urgent search for innovative dredging systems with a lower impact, but higher efficiency that dredging work can achieve off the coast and in urban delta. The United Arab Emirates (UAE) faces major challenges in terms of water security and water safety in the urban environment. Large and continuous growth means that living environments need to be expanded and preserved and the water supply and purification must be realised more efficiently. In addition to many innovations and investments required in this context, the (water) infrastructure in the urban delta and coastal waters must be prepared to achieve the water ambitions of the UAE, including through dredging. Although a lot of attention is paid to water and energy savings in the industry, dredging is still carried out through conventional techniques. This sector is extremely polluting because large ships are needed to operate the heavy dredging systems. The systems themselves also have a negative impact underwater because they cause water obfuscation (turbidity) which suffocates benthic organisms and coral. In addition, dredging by large ships has a negative effect on the coastal islands. Among other things for these reasons large ships are exiled off the coast of the UAE. This is an urgent search for innovative dredging systems with a lower impact, but higher efficiency that dredging work can achieve off the coast and in urban delta. Initial activities and results of the project:With the DrillCutter technology that DredgeYard has developed, the following advantages are achieved:  1.	Because the extraction channel is placed in/behind the cutting head, the extraction is directly at the source, increasing its effectiveness.2.	DredgeYard's cutting head can run at a speed of 90 RPM instead of the average 30 RPM, which again improves the efficiency of the system with Factor 9.3.	Water clouding (turbidity) decreases by 90% due to a closed system that leaves almost nothing behind, thus minimal impact on the soil.   This feasibility study is being carried out in preparation for a large-scale pilot phase in which dredgeyard's innovative dredging technology can be demonstrated in an operational environment. Before this can be done, research must be carried out into the long-term technical working principle (by means of endurance tests). The tests can also quantify the technical, economic and environmental advantages of the DrillCutter compared to current dredging technologies. This information is necessary to convince an end user to carry out a pilot project. The feasibility study covers the following activities:  1.	Research: Technical data from the end user must be collected. Further research is required in local laws and regulations that affect the development of the prototype. 2.	Development: Further development of the prototype in addition to the technical data collected from the end user.3.	Testing: in operational environment in the UAE for a duration of four weeks.4.	Collecting and analyzing data: energy / environment / operational costs / efficiency (speed and mass).  What makes the technology, product, method or approach used innovative:What are the results of the project:

Water sector policy and administrative management

Short general project overview:Harmful algal blooms are a globally increasing problem that are having severe consequences on the health of citizens, ecosystems and nature reserves around and downstream of the infected area. Also aquatic organisms living in the infected area are affected and may die. Specifically in larger catchment areas, nutrients have been building-up in the sediment from years of urban and agricultural pollution. Because of this, algal blooms will not easily be halted and solutions which are not chemical-based are scarce. LG Sonic, based in the Netherlands, is one of the few companies in the world, that has a viable solution to effectively reduce algal blooms without negatively affecting the aquatic ecosystem. The ultrasonic based solution that LG Sonic has invented has already been used successfully on smaller reservoirs (between 20 and 200 Ha of surface area) since 2011 and is currently the only technology present that seems to have a potential to be upscaled to even larger reservoirs and lakes. To do so however, LG Sonic will need to radically change the current design of the technology to make it fit for a wider range of waterbodies. They intent to do so, though this Partners For Water program, which will allow them to upscale their technology to solve this tremendous environmental problem globally. By developing the MPC-MultiBuoy (MPC-MBS), LG Sonic will have access to a wider range of lakes and reservoirs for which their current MPC-Buoy technology is not fit, such as:•	Lakes with a large surface area, which would otherwise require the installation of hundreds of MPC-Buoy systems. •	Lakes with a complicated shape or islands that would also require the installation of too many systems.•	Lakes and reservoirs that are remote or outside an area with cellular reception.•	Lakes and reservoirs in which the technology cannot be protected against theft or vandalism, either because they lie within an urban area or too far outside of it. LG Sonic is already advanced in the design of the MPC-MBS, and would like to use this program to speed-up the development of the system and facilitate a pilot of the technology. For the location of the pilot, we have chosen Dubai, mainly because the potential of upscaling after the pilot is very high here and the negotiations about the upscaling is already advanced. Another important reason is the presence of the local partner in Dubai Globe2Cloud (G2C), who is designing the communication method and can provide local support to the pilot installation. In Dubai Municipality lies the Al Marmoom Desert Conservation Reserve. This is the first unfenced nature conservation reserve in the United Arab Emirates. It is located in the desert area of Saih Al Salam in the emirate of Dubai and comprises some 10% of the total land area of the emirate, including the extensive man-made desert wetlands: the Al Qudra Lakes. Unfortunately, these lakes are filled with harmful algal blooms due to high phosphate levels.In 2018, LG Sonic has successfully demonstrated their MPC-Buoy technology in lake no. 44 in Dubai. The technology has reduced their phycocyanin levels (Blue-green algae) with 70% in this lake. Because of this, Dubai Municipality is eager to install the technology in their other 48 lakes as well.However, with the current MPC-Buoy technology, this would not be feasible, for the following reasons:•	The lakes have an odd shape and include many islands, which would require the installation of too many MPC-Buoy systems to effectively treat the entire surface area. •	The MPC-Buoy is completely based on the water, requiring a boat for maintenance activities. Due to local sandstorms and lack of rain, the MPC-Buoys need to be cleaned frequently. With the number of MPC-Buoys needed for all lakes (around 200), maintenance would become a fulltime activity. •	The lakes are in a remote area where the 3G/4G network is insufficient. The MPC-Buoys require a good connection to send water quality data via satellite to the LG Sonic office for analyzes and receive specific ultrasound frequency instructions based on this data.The MPC-MBS that LG Sonic is developing together with G2C will feature a shore-based power platform, that will include solar panels and batteries, along with an interactive station that can be used to inform the public about water quality. To this power station, multiple ultrasonic transmitters and sensors can be connected that can be placed at strategic locations in the lake. To do so however, LG Sonic and G2C need to restructure and redesign the ultrasonic transmitters and programs, develop an optimal communication protocol and design the on-shore power system. Dubai Municipality offers the consortium of LG Sonic (developer of MPC-MBS) and G2C a perfect pilot project to develop the MPC-MBS and to demonstrate it in a challenging operational environment with a highly interesting potential project request when good results are delivered.Initial activities and results of the project:To structure the work necessary to complete this project, the different activities in this study are divided into five different work packages.a.	WP1: Development in the Netherlands: Design and production of MBS construction, software and optimization of ultrasound.  b.	WP2: Development in Dubai: Selection, assembly and programming of telemetric system.  WP3: Integration of all components and local (NL) testing.c.	WP4: Installation and operation of the MPC-MBS, including training. d.	WP5: Validation of the project and dissemination to stakeholders. Objective: Validate the effect of the MPC-MBS to prevent algal blooms in the lakes. Define the potential to upscale to other sites.Core activities:•	Validation report and article: The validation report will be produced and shared with leading magazines in water technology industries, as well as conference programs •	Define further steps for upscaling: Based on the results in the reservoir and the validation results, LG Sonic and Globe2Cloud will look at the possibilities to further upscale the system. This will be specifically for the following points:1.	Determine the exact range of the multi buoys and look at possibilities to increase the range for larger water bodies.2.	Look at the possibilities to implement the system in other environments and weather conditions.   Definition of installation requirements: Finally, this project will lead to a set of requirements that can help LG Sonic and Globe2Cloud to implement the system in similar and different water bodies.
Water supply and sanitation - large systems

Water sector policy and administrative management

The overall objective of this project is to enhance EU-GCC energy relations by developing new appropriate structures and instruments and maintaining existing ones for practical cooperation activities of mutual interest in the area of clean energy technologies  Hence, building on the achievements of the EU-GCC clean energy network since 2010, the project is necessary to further the cooperation opportunities in the energy sector.
European Commission ¿ Service for Foreign Policy Instruments
